After a stay in Case Western Reserve University, USA, and Fritz Haber Institute of the Max Planck Society, Germany, he joined in Tsinghua University, China at 2011. Prof. Zhang's research focuses on energy materials such as Li-S batteries, Li metal anode, and electrocatalysts. He has been awarded the National Science Fund for Distinguished Young Scholars, the Young Top-Notch Talent from China, and the Newton Advanced Fellowship from the Royal Society, UK. Currently, Prof. Zhang is also an associate editor for the Journal of Energy Chemistry and sits on the advisory board of Matter, Advanced Functional Materials, Energy Storage Materials, Philosophical Transactions A, and so on. This work was supported by the Natural Scientific Foundation of China (21825501), National Key Research and Development Program ( 2016YFA0202500 and 2016YFA0200102 ), Australian Research Council (DP160103107, FT170100224), and Tsinghua University Initiative Scientific Research Program. Chuan Zhao is a Professor at the School of Chemistry at the University of New South Wales (UNSW), and the Head of UNSW Nanoelectrochemistry Lab. He also holds a Professorial Future Fellowship from Australian Research Council. He currently is the Chair of the Royal Australian Chemical Institute (RACI) Electrochemistry Division, and elected the Fellow of Royal Society of Chemistry (FRSC), Fellow of RACI (FRACI) and Fellow of Royal Society of New South Wales (FRSN). Prof Zhao received his PhD in 2002 with an excellence award from Northwest University, then completed postdoctoral research at University of Oldenburg and Monash University. He started his independent research career as a Lecturer at UNSW in Oct 2010, and was promoted to full Professor in 2017. Prof Chuan Zhao is interested in discovering novel electroactive nanomaterials and their implications to electrochemical energy storage and conversion, and sensors applications including water splitting, hydrogen fuel cells, CO 2 & N 2 reduction, and batteries. He has published more than 180 high impact research papers, and holds >10 patents of which 8 have been commercialised. 0 item S2095-4956(20)30251-5 S2095495620302515 1-s2.0-S2095495620302515 China ⁎ Corresponding author. The demand for efficient and environmentally-benign electrocatalysts that help availably harness the renewable energy resources is growing rapidly. In recent years, increasing insights into the design of water electrolysers, fuel cells, and metal–air batteries emerge in response to the need for developing sustainable energy carriers, in which the oxygen evolution reaction and the oxygen reduction reaction play key roles. However, both reactions suffer from sluggish kinetics that restricts the reactivity. Therefore, it is vital to probe into the structure of the catalysts to exploit high-performance bifunctional oxygen electrocatalysts. Spinel-type catalysts are a class of materials with advantages of versatility, low toxicity, low expense, high abundance, flexible ion arrangement, and multivalence structure. In this review, we afford a basic overview of spinel-type materials and then introduce the relevant theoretical principles for electrocatalytic activity, following that we shed light on the structure–property relationship strategies for spinel-type catalysts including electronic structure, microstructure, phase and composition regulation, and coupling with electrically conductive supports. We elaborate the relationship between structure and property, in order to provide some insights into the design of spinel-type bifunctional oxygen electrocatalysts. Graphical abstract The bifunctional oxygen reduction and oxygen evolution reactions on spinel-type electrocatalysts can be regulated through spinel structure, defect and valence engineering, phase and composition engineering, microstructure designing and coupling with metal-based and carbon-based supports. Image, graphical abstract Keywords Spinel electrocatalyst Bifunctional energy electrocatalysis Oxygen evolution reaction Oxygen reduction reaction Structure–property relationship 1 Introduction The rapid development of the modern society demands high consumption of energy that is largely dependent on fossil fuels, resulting in significant issues of resource scarcity and environmental pollution [1]. To this end, electricity derived from renewable resources has become a promising substitute to reducing the demanding reliance on traditional non-renewable resources [2]. In general, energy can be stored and converted by the cleavage and recombination of chemical bonds [3–5]. Innovative devices such as electrolysers, fuel cells, and metal–air batteries help promote rational utilization of renewable resources and exploit novel strategies for energy storage and conversion [6–10]. Typically, oxygen evolution reaction (OER) occurs at the anode and hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) reaction occurs at the cathode of a water electrolyser, while oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) and hydrogen oxidation reaction (HOR) occur at the cathode and anode of a fuel cell [11–20]. Analogously, metal–air batteries such as lithium–air and zinc–air batteries are among the most promising electrochemical storage systems due to their high energy density [21,22], but their bifunctional oxygen electrocatalysis performance at air electrode is inhibited due to sluggish kinetics. Compared to HER and HOR, which are both two-proton-coupled electron transfer processes, the OER and ORR, exhibit more complex mechanisms and sluggish kinetics, and thereby limit the reaction activity and efficiency. One of the most challenging problems in OER and ORR is exploring efficient earth abundance catalysts regarding commercial viability and environmental friendliness. Note that OER and ORR require different electrochemical conditions. To be more specific, the two reactions always require different optimal active sites. For example, Pt-based materials, being the state-of-the-art ORR catalysts, perform rather poorly in OER due to the oxidation of Pt on the surface of the catalysts at higher potentials [23]. On the contrary, while IrO2 and RuO2 are superior OER catalysts, they are not so effective toward ORR. Besides, it is not economically-effective to use two different catalysts in a working electrode, taking both fabrication complexity and high cost into consideration. In view of these demerits, searching and designing bifunctional oxygen electrocatalysts are highly demanded [12]. Carbon-based materials have been sought as an appropriate alternative to noble metals for ORR. However, they suffer strong corrosion and low duration for OER, even rapid degradation under higher potentials, resulting in intense oxidation current [24]. Compared to carbon-based materials, non-noble metallic compounds are relatively stable under harsh electrolytic conditions [25,26]. In view of their diverse properties, spinel compounds with the formulation of AB2X4 (A, B = metal, X = chalcogen) are a promising class of functional materials with tunable active sites [27,28]. Besides advantages like low cost, high abundance, low toxicity, and multiple valence, some spinel even present prominent Jahn–Teller effect [29]. In a typical spinel structure, X2– ions are closely packed, with A2+ and B3+ ions which occupying part or all tetrahedral sites and octahedral sites, respectively (Fig. 1 ) [30]. Diverse ion arrays and different exposed facets in the spinel structure have prominent effects on the electronic structure and chemical properties [31–34]. As a result, the OER/ORR performance is highly dependent on the diverse electronic structure such as the number of eg filling electrons, the corresponding spin state in spinel type compounds and the covalency of transition metal-oxygen bond [35–37]. Rational design of spinel-type compounds from different views is one of the crucial issues in oxygen electrocatalysis chemistry. This review focuses on regulating the structure of spinel−type electrocatalysts. OER/ORR mechanisms and activity descriptors are firstly presented. Then an overall account on prominent strategies for structure regulation of spinel-based bifunctional OER/ORR electrocatalysts including electronic structure, phase, composition, and microstructure is presented. Also, recent advances in the hybrid carbon or metal-based spinel electrocatalysts are introduced. These hybrids have better performance compared to single spinel compounds due to the synergistic effect of each component. Finally, we conclude by providing some insights into future directions of structure regulation in bifunctional OER/ORR of spinel compounds. 2 OER and ORR mechanism 2.1 Scaling relationships in electrocatalysis From the theoretical perspective, depending on the electrolyte composition, both OER and ORR undergo a four-proton-coupled electron transfer pathway [39–42]. Taking ORR as an example, which could be either a dissociative or associative mechanism, in associative ORR in alkaline electrolyte, the reaction proceeds initially through the HOO* formation step followed by its further reduction to O* and OH*, until ultimately OH– is formed. Alkaline OER occurs in the reverse order. (The asterisk represents the species absorbed on the surface.) Alkaline medium: (1) * + O2(g) + H2O(l) + e − ↔ HOO* + OH− (2) HOO* + e − ↔ O* + OH− (3) O*+ H2O(l) + e − ↔ HO* + OH− (4) OH* + e − ↔ OH− + * (5) Overall: O2 + 4e− +2H2O ↔ 4OH− Acid medium: (6) * + O2(g) + e − + H + ↔ HOO* (7) HOO* + e − + H + ↔ O* + H2O (8) O* + e − + H + ↔ HO* (9) OH* + e − + H + ↔ H2O + * (10) Overall: O2 + 4H+ + 4e− ↔ 2H2O The reaction coordinate shown in Fig. 2 describes the energy changes of the system as the reactants move from an initial state to a final state along a reaction pathway. Sufficient energy is requested for the reactant to get over the energy barrier, which is referred to as activation energy (ΔG ‡), and for the reaction to proceed. Catalysts provide an alternative path with reduced activation energy. At the top of the energy barrier, the reaction is at its transition state, which is the point where the energetics of bond forming or breaking has equal probability of moving from the transition state toward either the reactant or the product basin. However, not all transition states have been measured. Only some specific ones which are referred to as intermediates as well as the initial reactant states and the final product states are easy to be probed through in situ analysis and operando measurements with higher resolution. It is noteworthy that these states can be correlated to transition states by linear free energy relationships (LFERs) [43]. Conceptually, LFER is used to depict the change in activation energy, which scales with the variation in intermediate free energy when an intrinsic variable (electric potential ϕ, chemical potential μ, temperature T, pressure p, etc.) is tuned. There is LFER between the electrochemical free energy of reaction intermediates and the reaction rate [36], that is: lnk=alnK+b, where k represents the kinetic rate constant and K denotes the thermodynamic equilibrium constant, a, b are constants. In the formula above, k is expressed as k = k 0exp(−ΔG ‡/RT), while the relation between K and free energy of intermediate is ΔG=−RTlnK. For this reason, an extra electrochemical overpotential must be applied to ensure that the intermediate free energies for all four steps along the reaction coordinates are spontaneous [44]. Fig. 3 (a) illustrates the adsorption free energy of the intermediates in OER/ORR. At equilibrium 1.23 V (vs. reversible hydrogen electrode, RHE), the free energy increases for the transformation of OOH* from O2 in ORR, which means an overpotential must be applied to make this step proceed spontaneously. Similarly, for the formation of HOO* from O* in OER, the free energy also increases. Consequently, applying a potential bias from the equilibrium 1.23 V is essential to make all the elementary steps proceed spontaneously, thus causing thermodynamic overpotentials. The ideal condition is that there is no deviation in the intermediate free energies at equilibrium potential and the transition between the intermediates for OER/ORR would be spontaneous. However, the non-zero overpotential is indispensable for the adsorption free energy of different intermediates are linearly correlated with each other and cannot be regulated independently (Fig. 3(b)). More specifically, when one intermediate adsorption free energy is tuned, the others will scale with it, which is referred to as scaling relationships [45]. Scaling relationships provide an instructional principle for bifunctional catalyst design on various surfaces [39,40,46]. According to the elementary steps of OER/ORR, the free energy of each step can be expressed as follows, taking OER in acid medium as an example: Δ G 1 = Δ G OH − Δ G H 2 O = Δ G OH (11) ( There is a caveat that Δ G H 2 O = 0 ) (12) Δ G 2 = Δ G O − Δ G OH (13) Δ G 3 = Δ G OOH − Δ G O (14) Δ G 4 = Δ G O 2 − Δ G OOH The activity is defined as the negative change in free energy (−ΔG). Fig. 3(c,d) depicts the volcano plots of metal oxide and metal surfaces calculated by the aforementioned scaling relationships, respectively [46]. The slopes of the two branches in one volcano plot are dissimilar. The adsorption free energy of the intermediates in OER/ORR is denoted as ΔG O, ΔG OH, and ΔG OOH. ΔG OH and ΔG OOH have a 1:1 scaling relationship, while ΔG O has a 2:1 scaling with ΔG OH and ΔG OOH due to the double bond to the surface of adsorbed O* [39]. The OER activity is limited by the HOO* (green line) and the O* (red line) formation steps, respectively, while the ORR activity is limited by the HO* (blue line) and O2 reduction (black line) steps. The two vertices do not overlap, which indicates that OER and ORR cannot have an optimal activity simultaneously (more specifically, at the same ΔG O which means for one material) due to the intrinsic active sites required by OER and ORR are not consistent. The shape of volcano plot is highly dependent on scaling relationship, which ties with the chemical environment of catalyst. In other words, for one targeted catalyst, if the chemical environment of its atoms were changed, the shape of its volcano plots for both OER and ORR vary correspondingly. Consequently, it is vital to adopt proper strategies to regulate the scaling relationships to reduce the distance between the vertices of the OER/ORR volcano plots and to optimize the performance of bifunctional electrocatalysts. 2.2 Activity descriptors and mechanism proposed for spinel-type oxygen electrocatalysts To better understand the role of different components in spinel, it is important to identify the activity descriptor of spinel-type oxygen electrocatalysts. The d-band state model was applied to predict and understand the catalytic activity. Generally speaking, the d-band state model has been established to describe the coupling between the metal d-states and the valence state of the adsorbates which determines the adsorption energy and thus renders the catalytic activity. Inspired by the success of d-band center modelling in elucidating catalytic reactions over various metal surfaces [47–51], and the established activity descriptors for the perovskite family, i.e. number of d electrons [52,53], eg occupancy [54,55], bulk formation energy [53], metal–oxygen covalency [36,54], and the position of the oxygen-p band center [56,57], Xu et al. proposed the eg occupancy of the cations at octahedral sites as the activity descriptor of spinel electrocatalysts (Fig. 4 (a,b)) [38]. Similar to perovskite electrocatalysts, spinel is a family of complex compounds with two different sites at their structures occupied by various transitional metal cations with a wide range of valence states. In octahedral coordination, the high-lying eg orbits directly points to O and generates a strong overlap with an O-2p orbit, while in tetrahedral sites, the high-lying eg and the low-lying t2g orbits have a rather weak interaction with the O-2p orbit. As a consequence, octahedral site cations are suggested to play a leading role in determining the OER/ORR activity. It was concluded that e g filling of the octahedral element and the occupation of the octahedral site by the active elements simultaneously govern oxygen electrocatalysis performance [38]. Fig. 4(c) illustrates the according four electron/proton-coupled mechanism that can be classified as acid–base mechanism where Moct refers to the metal cation at the octahedral sites [38]. In this mechanism, the rate-limiting steps in ORR are step 1 and step 4 while the rate-limiting steps in OER are step 2 and step 3. The Moct–O2− bonding strength of the spinel oxides on the left branch (eg<1) of the volcano plot is rather strong for ORR, which hinders the OH− regeneration. While as to the right branch (eg>1), the reaction rate is limited by the formation of strong Moct–OO2−. Similarly, the formation of Moct–OO2− is limited by the proton removal from Moct–OOH− for eg electron filling in spinel oxidess on the left branch, and the O–O bond formation in the Moct–OOH− is restricted by the electron over-filling in eg orbits on the right branch of OER volcano plot. Therefore, both ORR and OER activities should be optimized at a moderate eg filling (eg ≈ 1) at the octahedral site, which can balance the competition between rate-limiting steps. Apart from cations at the octahedral sites, metal–oxygen hybridization degree is an alternative activity descriptor for spinel-type oxygen electrocatalysts. Xu et al. also investigated the tuning effect on the eg number in the OER catalytic performance of ZnFe2− x Cr x O4 [58,59]. As the Cr content increases to the Fe/Cr ratio of 1/1, the nominal eg electron filling number at an octahedral site is unity with the highest activity. The tuning effect is attributed to the super-exchange interactions between octahedral site cations which tunes their eg filling. It is the electron transfer from the unfilled d orbits between Fe to Cr that promotes the OER catalytic performance. With the aid of DFT calculations, it is manifested that the TMOh 3d–O 2p hybridization degree is also tuned by the gradual substitution of Cr, which is positively in correlation to the OER activity. 3 Structure regulation of spinel-type bifunctional oxygen electrocatalyst Directed by thermodynamic scaling relationships between intermediate steps and activity descriptors in the spinel structure, in this part, we elaborate some typical strategies to regulate the structure, thereby promoting the bifunctional electrocatalytic activity. The electrocatalytic performance of spinel electrocatalyst is highly dependent on the parameters including composition, structure as well as distribution and oxidation state of cations [60–63]. Often, tailoring electronic structure can tune the intrinsic activity by optimizing the surface adsorption free energies [64,65]. Engineering electronic structure is a widespread strategy in catalysts design and can be achieved by creating structure defects, heteroatom doping and regulating the relative anions in the composition to generate different active sites [66–70]. Furthermore, exposing different phases to reactants and coupling the active material with different substrates are also effective approaches to regulating the electronic structure, thus influencing the performance. Besides, different morphologies have high impacts on the performance of bifunctional electrocatalysts by influencing the mass diffusion and charge transfer properties. In this section, we summarize some main strategies to regulate the electronic structure and morphology of spinel electrocatalysts. 3.1 Engineering defect An effective way to improve the electrocatalytic activity is to increase the extent of deficiency species within spinel crystal lattice of the oxide structure, especially oxygen vacancies [26]. The importance of oxygen vacancies has been widely elucidated in various electrochemical systems, i.e. lithium ion batteries and oxide fuel cells [68,71–74]. Liu et al. reported spinel-structured NiCo2O4 nanosheets with oxygen defects as a bifunctional oxygen electrocatalyst [75]. Oxygen vacancies were induced in the Ni-Co hydroxide precursors through a sequent calcination approach. NiCo2O4 spinel was exposed to air, O2, and Ar/H2 clacination and the density of O vacancies was compared for the calcinated species by means of high resolution O 1 s XPS spectrum. It was illustrated that the specimen calcined in air atmosphere, denoted as NiCo-air, assumes higher relative intensity of oxygen vacancies (Fig. 5 (a,b)). The NiCo-air sample was demonstrated to exhibit improved OER and ORR activity and benign catalytic durability in a continuous polarization over 1000 cycles (Fig. 5(c,d)). The improvement in catalytic performance was attributed to the introduction of oxygen vacancies which enhanced the interaction between oxygen-containing intermediates and catalyst surface. Thus, the introducing of oxygen vacancies can effectively regulate the electronic structure and optimize the surface adsorption feature of oxygen-containing intermediates to augment the activity. Apart from Ni and Co-based spinel oxide, Fe-based spinel oxides also have the potential for both OER and ORR [76]. 3.2 Controlling valence Among various candidates for bifunctional oxygen electrocatalysis, Mn- and Co-based materials stand out as promising catalysts due to their excellent redox property originating from their multivalence nature [77–81]. By controlling the cationic valence, the number of d-electron in the transition metal cation is varied, thereby the electronic/ionic conductivity of the electrocatalysts and the reaction kinetics can be improved [82,83]. Lately, Suib's group synthesized Ni- and Mn- promoted Co3O4 via an inverse micelle process [68]. Taking Ni as an example, by tuning the incorporation level of Ni, the crystallization of Co3O4 was hindered and the crystallographic disorder in the Co−Ni−O mixed oxides was decreased. Among all samples, 5%Ni-Co demonstrated the most prominent ORR activity with a potential of 0.83 V to deliver a current density of −3.0 mA cm–2, comparable to that of state-of-the-art Pt/C catalyst. Similarly, 5%Ni-Co displayed the lowest overpotential of 0.381 V in OER to reach a current density of 10 mA cm–2 and surpassed the state-of-the-art OER Ir/C catalyst at a high potential over 1.64 V. Maiyalagan et al. synthesized a lithiated spinel structure {Li2}16c[Co 2]16dO4 at low temperatures (~ 400 °C) denoted as LT-LiCoO2 (Fig. 6 (a,b)) [67]. A counterpart of the LiCoO2 oxide was synthesized at high temperature for comparison, designated as HT-LiCoO2. LT-LiCoO2 had cubane-like cubic Co4O4 units, while HT-LiCoO2 was consisted of LiCo3O4 units. Mixed-valent oxides generally exhibit high ORR activity, as well as excellent OER activity [84]. In this regard, lithium is chemically extracted from LT-LiCoO2 to generate LT-Li1− x CoO2 (0<x<0.5) with mixed-valent Co3+/4+. The LT-Li0.5CoO2 exhibited exceptional ORR performance as well as good OER performance and stability (Fig. 6(c,d)). The high ORR and OER activities of delithiated compositions were ascribed to the emerged Co4O4 cubane subunits (Fig. 6e) and a pinning of the Co3+/4+:3d energy with the top of the O2−:2p band (Fig. 6f). Therefore, the widespread span of valence endows spinel with a potential prospect for serving as high-performance bifunctional electrocatalysts with dense active sites. 3.3 Engineering microstructure Spinel nanoparticles often suffer from aggregation and poor intrinsic electronic conductivity. Therefore, it is of vital importance to probe various morphologies to avert these problems [87–90]. By engineering microstructure, more active sites are exposed, which can render the catalysts with enhanced reactivity. Numerous endeavors have been dedicated to synthesize spinel oxides with diverse microstructures, from one-dimensional nanotubes to multi-dimensional nanoflowers, nanocages, and nano-octahedrons, etc. [85,86,91–98]. What's more, porous spinel catalysts are a class of promising candidate for bifunctional oxygen electrocatalysts. The abundant pores are conductive to the diffusion of feeding gas thus expediting mass transfer as well as achieving intimate contacts with the active sites. Recently, Wang et al. fabricated mesoporous thin-walled CuCo2O4@C nanotubes with abundant nitrogen-doping by coaxial electrospinning technique and used it as a bifunctional electrocatalyst for Zn–air batteries [93]. The as-fabricated CuCo2O4@C nanotubes exhibited superb OER activity with only a small overpotential of 327 mV to achieve a current density of 10 mA cm−2 as well as a positive half-wave potential of 0.850 V vs RHE for ORR in alkaline media. The superior bifunctional activity of CuCo2O4@C nanotubes was attributed to the unique microstructural characteristics including (i) numerous mesopores arranging channels for oxygen escape as well as hydroxyl diffusion; (ii) increased electrochemically active surface area offering more exposed active sites for the interface catalytic reaction; and (iii) interconnected one-dimensional open-ended nanotubes morphology providing superior electronic contact for the external circuit. To demonstrate the effective role of porous microstructures, needle-like NiCo2O4 clusters with abundant meso‑ and macropores were fabricated using a soft-template method (Fig. 7 (b)) [85]. Meanwhile, the as-fabricated structure with sphere morphology using SiO2 hard template (Fig. 7(c)) as well as the a typical needle-like counterpart (Fig. 7(a)) synthesized via a template-free method was used as control samples. Fig. 7(d,e) demonstrates the electrocatalytic performance of these samples in comparison to each corresponding benchmark catalyst, respectively. The soft-templated porous needle-like NiCo2O4 catalyst exhibits the best ORR activity with an onset potential of 0.94 V and a half-wave potential of 0.82 V, comparative to that of Pt/C. In the case of OER, the porous needlelike NiCo2O4 presents an overpotential of ~ 350 mV at the current density of 10 mA cm−2 superior to that of Ir/C. On the contrary, the sphere-like counterpart exhibits rather weak bifunctional activity, partly due to the lack of porous morphology as well as the existence of SiO2 impurity. Therefore, the porous needle-like clusters consist of abundant NiCo2O4 single crystals facilitating both the dispersion and better accessibility of active sites as well as structural robustness. Besides, a self-assembled three-dimensional foam-like NiCo2O4 catalyst was also synthesized using starch as the template which demonstrated superior bifunctional electrocatalytic activities toward both OER and ORR (Fig. 7(f-i)) [86]. Si et al. reported mesoporous nanostructured spinel-type MFe2O4 (M=Co, Mn, Ni) loaded on carbon support to illustrate M-dependent catalytic activities [92]. Different M-site metals showed various microstructures and morphologies where M-site is octahedral site. CoFe2O4 and NiFe2O4 samples both consisted of nanowire networks and sub-micron particles, while the MnFe2O4 sample demonstrated a nanosheet morphology. The potential gap between the OER potential at the current density of 10.0 mA cm−2 and the ORR potential at −3.0 mA cm−2 for CoFe2O4 was only 0.89 V, obviously smaller than those of MnFe2O4 (1.06 V), NiFe2O4 (0.90 V) and Pt/C (1.03 V). DFT calculation further demonstrates a modest d-band center which offers a compatible adsorption of O2 and desorption of oxygenated intermediates. Therefore, CoFe2O4 sample was revealed to be one of the most promising bifunctional electrocatalysts. 3.4 Modulating phase and composition The electrocatalytic performance of spinel compounds can also be improved by modulating the phase structures including tetrahedral, cubic, and even inverse spinel phases [99–102]. Among various types of spinels, MMn2O4 (M represents divalent metal elements such as Co, Mg and Zn) is one of the most intriguing composites due to the unique physiochemical properties of manganese and multiple valences. In 2011, Chen's group presented a facile and rapid strategy to prepare the nanocrystalline spinel Co x Mn3– x O4 as a bifunctional OER/ORR electrocatalyst by reducing the amorphous MnO2 in an aqueous solution containing Co2+ [29]. In the presence of strong reductants such as NaBH4 and N2H4•H2O, the tetrahedral phase was resulted with the CoMn2O4 composition, while under weak reductant agents such as NaH2PO2, Mn (IV) in MnO2 precursor was merely partially reduced, forming a cubic phase. Valence electron arrangement was taken to account for this phenomenon. The valence arrangement of Mn (III) is 3d 4, which tends to exhibit John-Teller effect [62], thus inducing lower crystallographic symmetry. Nanocrystalline Co x Mn3– x O4 spinels were denoted as CoMnO–P and CoMnO–B where NaH2PO2 and NaBH4 were used as reductants, respectively. As a consequence, the major yielded phase was determined to as tetrahedral for CoMnO–B and cubic for CoMnO–P. Afterwards, the cubic phase spinel outperformed the tetrahedral phase in intrinsic ORR activity, while the tetrahedral phase spinel surpassed the cubic phase for OER (Fig. 8 ). The observed difference in electrocatalytic performance was attributed to the different binding energies of oxygen adsorption on cobalt and manganese defect sites. DFT calculations were performed to probe into the correlation between activity and phase and defect sites. Taking ORR performance as an example, in that OER is the reverse process of ORR, the cubic (113) surface shows an increase in the adsorbed oxygen-induced d-band generating a more strengthened Metal–O2 bond than the tetrahedral (121) surface, thereby, the more stable oxygen adsorbates. What's more, the number of active sites per surface unit cell is identical in the two phases, but the area of cubic (113) surface is smaller, thus the number of effective active sites is larger in one given area. As a result, the intrinsic ORR activity of cubic Co–Mn–O spinel is better. Later in 2015, Chen's group reported a new solution-based strategy for the controllable synthesis of cubic/tetragonal dual-phase spinel, with an unprecedented wide composition (Co x Mn3– x O4, 1<x<2) at a mild temperature (180 °C) [103]. The valence arrangement of Mn (III) is 3d 4 which is prone to the John-Teller distortion. The Co/Mn ratio is crucial for the determination of the crystallographic phase of cobalt-manganese spinel. For the electrocatalytic performance, especially ORR, the cubic-phase spinel outperformed the corresponding tetragonal phases with the same composition. Within the composition range of 0<x<2, the cubic spinel phase was achieved, and the activity increased with a higher Mn content, showing a significant phase and composition co-dependent performance. The cubic-spinel surface can not only provide more catalytic sites but also bind O2 more strongly than the tetragonal phase. Besides, the cubic phases featured a higher average oxidation state of Mn (>3) with a mixed form of Mn3+ and Mn4+ cations, which promote the electronic conductivity by enhancing electron hopping mechanism and improve the charge transfer through redox reactions. Other than normal Co x Mn3– x O4 spinel, inverse spinel systems have also been developed as oxygen electrocatalysts. Unlike the normal spinel structure, the chemical formula of inverse spinel structure is presented as B[AB]O4 with all of A cations and partial B cations residing in octahedral interstices, whereas tetrahedral sites being filled entirely with B cations in equal proportions [104]. What's more, mixed-phase transition metal oxides are potential candidates for oxygen bifunctional electrocatalysis due to their high-abundance, easy attainment, as well as structure flexibility and property versatility. Liu, Hor, and co-workers reported a dual-phase MnCo2O4 system, denoted as dp-MnCo2O4, in which the two constituent phases were [Mn1/3Co2/3][Mn 1/3Co 2/3]2O4 and (Co, Mn)[Mn, Co]2O4, respectively [105]. These two phases are intermediate spinel structures between the normal and inverse spinel structures, with the chemical formula of (A1− x B x )][A x /2B1− x /2]2O4. The former involved a thoroughly random distribution of Co and Mn cations within the cubic close-packed oxygen anion lattice, while in the case of (Co, Mn)[Mn, Co]2O4, Mn cations preferentially occupied the tetrahedral sites and displaced some of Co cations into the octahedral sites. As a result, Besides, the proportion of Co3+ cations occupying the remained octahedral sites was increased compared to the homogeneous cubic [Mn1/3Co2/3][Mn 1/3Co 2/3]2O4. According to the ORR and OER polarization curves, the MnCo2O4 phase spinel outperformed the other samples, i.e. MnCo0.5O2.5 and MnCo1.2O1.8. The existence of surface Co3+ plays a key role in OER activity [106–108], while the Mn4+/Mn3+ redox couples at the octahedral site assume the ORR active sites [107,109,110]. 3.5 Coupling catalyst with support Most spinel oxides suffer from poor electrical conductivity and low structural robustness, and some also endure poor O2-binding and activation ability [103]. Designing reasonable hybrid systems with conductive supports is demonstrated as an effective strategy to improve electrical conductivity and to provide prominent synergistic effect. The supporting materials fall into two categories, carbon supports (various composites of carbon [105], graphene [111,112], carbon nanotubes (CNTs) [105], etc.) and metal supports (Ni [66], Cu, etc.). 3.5.1 Carbon-based support Numerous attempts have been made to create spinel/nanocarbon hybrid systems to improve the electrical conductivity of transitional metal mixed oxides [34,113–117]. Ge et al. reported the covalent coupling phenomenon between MnCo2O4 nanocrystals with mixed cubic and tetragonal phases (denoted as dp-MnCo2O4) and nanocarbon supports, namely, CNTs and nitrogen-doped reduced graphene oxide (N-rGO) (Fig. 9 (a,b)). The hybrid system exhibited comparable bifunctional OER/ORR electrocatalytic performance to commercial 30 wt% Pt/C [105]. Introducing the nanocarbon support helped to establish covalent interfacial Mn–O–C interactions in dp-MnCo2O4/CNT hybrid as well as Mn–N–C in dp-MnCo2O4/N-rGO hybrid. The electron cloud sharing between C and O or N reduces the electron cloud density around Mn. Consequently, the molecular orbital sharing by MnCo2O4 and nanocarbon shifted the Mn4+/Mn3+ redox couple to the Mn3+ end, leading to improved bifunctional oxygen activities. Fig. 9(c,d) shows the ORR and OER LSV curves of different dp-MnCo2O4 catalysts. It is worth nothing that the ORR performance of dp-MnCo2O4/CNT surpassed that of the physically mixed counterpart (Fig. 9(c)), demonstrating the effect of the spinel/nanocarbon hybridization strategy. The OER performance of the reported dp-MnCo2O4/N-rGO hybrid, is almost identical to that of the benchmark catalyst Ir/C, further confirming the effectiveness of valence coupling between spinel oxide and nanocarbon. Besides ORR, both hybrids systems demonstrated superior OER performance (Fig. 9(d)). The integration of metal oxides and nanocarbon promotes the formation of conductive networks [118–120], facilitates charge transfer and well-disperse the oxide nanocrystals in case of aggregation, ultimately resulting in significant improvement in catalytic activity. Apart from dual-phase spinel oxide and nanocarbon hybrids, Lee et al. reported a one-pot process to synthesize a hybrid system composed of mesoporous NiCo2O4 nanoplatelets and graphene sheets (NiCo2O4–G) [111], as a simple, cost-effective, and highly efficient way for producing large quantities of nanomaterials. In the prepared hybrid, graphene served as a conductive support and in the meantime also facilitated the charge transfer. Furthermore, In the previously mentioned Co x Mn3– x O4 spinel with cubic/tetragonal phases [29], the cubic phase was also hybridized with carbon support denoted as c-CoMn2/C. The obtained hybrid significantly enhanced ORR/OER performances in comparison to the physical mixture of two components. The ORR activity of the hybrid rivaled that of the benchmark Pt/C catalyst, that is, equivalent Pt nanoparticles supported on carbon. The hybrid system also outperformed Ir/C counterpart for OER activity. The outstanding bifunctionality was attributed to not only the high intrinsic activity of c-CoMn2 spinel, but also the strong synergy between the spinel oxide and the carbon support as well as the well-dispersed spinel nanocrystals on the carbon framework [103]. 3.5.2 Metal-based support Metal supports serve as an effective alternative to carbon-based support to offering a conductive matrix to improve the bifunctional performance of oxygen electrocatalysis [26]. Lambert et al. reported a template-less electrodeposition approach to synthesize Co3O4 and Ni x Co3− x O4 films on nickel foil (Fig. 9(e,f)) [66]. The Co3O4 outperformed the Ir/C catalyst in ORR, while the hybrid spinel oxide Ni0.6Co2.4O4/Ni promoted the ORR activity with the inclusion of Ni in the catalyst structure and outperformed Pt/C catalyst in reactivity. Although 20% Pt/C film exhibited a lower onset potential shifted by 0.072 V, Ni0.6Co2.4O4 exhibited a ~ 30% higher half-wave current density of −3.29 mA cm−2 and also a higher steady state current density of −6.57 mA cm−2 than those of 20% Pt/C film (Fig. 9(g)). For OER performance, both Co3O4 and Ni0.6Co2.4O4 outperformed the benchmark Ir/C with lower E 10 of 1.76 V, compared to 1.85 V for Ir/C catalyst (Fig. 9(h)). In a nutshell, it was revealed that the ORR and OER activities of both Co3O4 and the spinel oxide Ni x Co3− x O4 with Ni substrate were better than that of Pt/C and Ir/C, respectively. This was attributed to both continuous porous high surface area of the spinel oxide itself as well as the intimate contact with the Ni substrate. 4 Conclusions and perspectives Recent advances in spinel-type bifunctional oxygen electrocatalysts are summarized starting by a basic introduction of spinel materials, followed by theoretical considerations on bifunctional oxygen electrocatalysis. ORR/OER mechanisms were elucidated based on thermodynamic scaling relationships between different intermediates and an overview of activity descriptors for spinel-based oxygen electrocatalysts. In the following part, we summarized the important strategies to regulate OER/ORR bifunctional activity of spinel electrocatalysts as manifested below. To improve the bifunctional OER and ORR performance of spinel-based electrocatalysts, it requires to anchor onto the main factors hampering the reactivity naemly the intrinsic electronic structure, sluggish charge transfer and low electrical conductivity. The volcano plot is used to guide the rational design of electrocatalysts. The electronic structure of the cations in the octahedral sites of the spinel structure as well as the metal–oxygen hybridization degree are critical activity descriptors for the spinel-type oxygen electrocatalysts. Driven by volcano plot, the introduced innate properties as well as activity descriptors, the structure–property relationship of the spinel-based electrocatalysts can be probed. More specifically, the electrocatalytic performance can be optimized through regulating the intrinsic activity of the active sites and extrinsic variation of morphology. Typically, a multi-scale strategy based on regulating various innate properties of spinel materials including electronic structure regulation, microstructure engineering, phase and composition modulation, to interfacial coupling is explored to this goal. As different catalytic sites exist in a spinel unit cell, the electronic structure can be readily regulated by doping or defect engineering, such as heteroatom doping or oxygen (metal) vacancies. Phase and composition modulation can alter the octahedral sites and change the oxidation states, resulting in an optimized surface adsorption energy and enhanced kinetics. The optimization of microstructure and interfacial coupling can also accelerate the mass diffusion, electron conductivity, and interfacial charge transfer. Considering the advantages offered by using spinel oxides, further progress and development in spinel-type materials beyond oxides is highly anticipated, such as sulfides [121–124], carbides, nitrides [117], chalcogenides [125]. It will afford a wide range of advanced materials with unique regulated electronic and crystal structures, thereby offering new opportunities in the field of electrocatalysis and beyond. Xiao-Meng Liu received her B.S. degree from the Department of Inorganic Nonmetallic Materials Engineering, Dalian University of Technology in 2017 and is currently pursuing her M.S. degree in the Department of Chemical Engineering, Tsinghua University. Her research interests focus on electrocatalysis. Xiaoyang Cui received her PhD in 2016 in the School of Materials Science and Engineering, Tsinghua University. She is currently working as a postdoctoral research associate in the Department of Chemical Engineering, Tsinghua University. Her main research interest is focused on nanostructured functional materials and their application in sustainable energy, especially on rational design of electrocatalysts along with electrochemical systems for oxygen reduction reaction, oxygen evolution reaction, and nitrogen reduction reaction under ambient conditions. Kamran Dastafkan joined the Nano-Electrochemistry Lab in the research group of Professor Chuan Zhao, School of Chemistry, the University of New South Wales, Sydney, Australia, in 2017. Being passionate about nanochemistry, Kamran started his Ph.D. in nano-electrocatalysis, surface, and solid-state chemistry for water splitting research. Before that, he was a part of Young Researchers and Elite Club in Iran conducting research in areas like nanofabrication and nanoadsorption. Hao-Fan Wang received his B.S. and Ph.D. degrees from the Department of Chemical Engineering, Tsinghua University in 2013 and 2018, respectively. He is currently a postdoctoral researcher in AIST-Kyoto University Chemical Energy Materials Open Innovation Laboratory (ChEM-OIL). His research interests include carbon materials, MOF-derived materials, and their applications in electrocatalysis and metal–air batteries. Cheng Tang received his B.Eng. and Ph.D. from the Department of Chemical Engineering, Tsinghua University in 2013 and 2018, respectively, under the supervision of Prof. Qiang Zhang and Prof. Fei Wei. Currently, he is a postdoctoral researcher at The University of Adelaide working with Prof. Shi-Zhang Qiao. His research focuses on nanomaterials and energy electrocatalysis, including 3D graphene, hierarchical nanomaterials, oxygen reduction/evolution, hydrogen evolution, nitrogen reduction, etc. Chuan Zhao is a Professor at the School of Chemistry at the University of New South Wales (UNSW), and the Head of UNSW Nanoelectrochemistry Lab. He also holds a Professorial Future Fellowship from Australian Research Council. He currently is the Chair of the Royal Australian Chemical Institute (RACI) Electrochemistry Division, and elected the Fellow of Royal Society of Chemistry (FRSC), Fellow of RACI (FRACI) and Fellow of Royal Society of New South Wales (FRSN). Prof Zhao received his PhD in 2002 with an excellence award from Northwest University, then completed postdoctoral research at University of Oldenburg and Monash University. He started his independent research career as a Lecturer at UNSW in Oct 2010, and was promoted to full Professor in 2017. Prof Chuan Zhao is interested in discovering novel electroactive nanomaterials and their implications to electrochemical energy storage and conversion, and sensors applications including water splitting, hydrogen fuel cells, CO2 & N2 reduction, and batteries. He has published more than 180 high impact research papers, and holds >10 patents of which 8 have been commercialised. Aibing Chen is a professor at Hebei University of Science and Technology, China. He earned his Ph.D. from Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences. His research interests are focused on the fields of physical chemistry of materials, porous carbon materials and its applications in energy conversion and storage, adsorption separation, CO2 capture and conversion, catalytic conversion. Chuanxin He received his Ph.D. in polymer chemistry and physics from University of Science and Technology of China in 2010. He joined the Department of Chemistry at Shenzhen University in 2010, promoted to Associate Professor in 2012 and Professor in 2019. His current research interesting is to design and synthesize novel nanostructure materials for fuel cells, water splitting and electrochemical reduction of carbon dioxide. So far, he published more than 80 journal papers, including Nature Communications, Journal of the American Chemical Society, Advanced Materials, Advanced Energy Materials, Angewandte Chemie International Edition, and so on. Minghan Han received his Ph.D. in Chemical Engineering from the University of Petroleum, China in 1997. He worked as a postdoctoral researcher at the Department of Chemical Engineering, Tsinghua University during Jun. 1997 to Aug. 1999. He has worked in the department since Sep. 1999, and was promoted as a professor in chemical engineering in 2011. He worked as a visiting scholar at the Stuttgart University, Germany from Apr. 2001 to May 2002 and as a Humboldt fellow at Dortmund University, Germany from Jul. 2004 to Jun. 2005, respectively. His research specializes in green catalysis and chemical reaction engineering, and his research interests mainly focus on applied catalysis for environmentally friendly, energy- and material-efficient chemical processes. Qiang Zhang received his bachelor and Ph.D. degree from Tsinghua University, China in 2004 and 2009, respectively. After a stay in Case Western Reserve University, USA, and Fritz Haber Institute of the Max Planck Society, Germany, he joined in Tsinghua University, China at 2011. Prof. Zhang's research focuses on energy materials such as Li-S batteries, Li metal anode, and electrocatalysts. He has been awarded the National Science Fund for Distinguished Young Scholars, the Young Top-Notch Talent from China, and the Newton Advanced Fellowship from the Royal Society, UK. Currently, Prof. Zhang is also an associate editor for the Journal of Energy Chemistry and sits on the advisory board of Matter, Advanced Functional Materials, Energy Storage Materials, Philosophical Transactions A, and so on.

coredata.dc:description: The demand for efficient and environmentally-benign electrocatalysts that help availably harness the renewable energy resources is growing rapidly. In recent years, increasing insights into the design of water electrolysers, fuel cells, and metal–air batteries emerge in response to the need for developing sustainable energy carriers, in which the oxygen evolution reaction and the oxygen reduction reaction play key roles. However, both reactions suffer from sluggish kinetics that restricts the reactivity. Therefore, it is vital to probe into the structure of the catalysts to exploit high-performance bifunctional oxygen electrocatalysts. Spinel-type catalysts are a class of materials with advantages of versatility, low toxicity, low expense, high abundance, flexible ion arrangement, and multivalence structure. In this review, we afford a basic overview of spinel-type materials and then introduce the relevant theoretical principles for electrocatalytic activity, following that we shed light on the structure–property relationship strategies for spinel-type catalysts including electronic structure, microstructure, phase and composition regulation, and coupling with electrically conductive supports. We elaborate the relationship between structure and property, in order to provide some insights into the design of spinel-type bifunctional oxygen electrocatalysts.
